abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings show satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, though only modest
            institutional development impacts. Despite being too early
            to draw firm lessons on the project's operation, and
            strategy, some tentative lessons convey experiences to
            consider, as follows. The approach of using a one-tranche
            operation, has seemingly worked, particularly as it relates
            to the operation within the context of the Country
            Assistance Strategy (CAS). Likewise, the strategic approach,
            seems particularly suited for a government, where its
            ability to implement a reform program, needs a further
            confident reestablishment, and, this in turn suggests that
            it might be useful to conduct an Intensive Learning
            Implementation Completion Report, following the next one, or
            two one-tranche adjustment operations. Nonetheless, it will
            be important to maintain a medium-to-long term focus on the
            actions supported, if such one-tranche operations are to be
            implemented in the context of the CAS, so as to ensure a
            timely start on measures requiring a longer lead time.
            Similarly, implementation of actions already taken, should
            be ensured, to sustain the effective momentum of their
            intended outcomes. However, it is important to review the
            government's bold devolution program, since both
            opportunities, and risks have been identified: opportunities
            include a greater voice for the country's people;
            conversely, risks include a potential disconnect between
            national, and local priorities, particularly where
            traditional elites have not fully appreciated the benefits
            of social actions.
